data.title: Sharp comedy gets boost from characters who swap genders
authors: Michael Grossberg For The Columbus Dispatch, The Columbus Dispatch
data.meta_description: Two actors pose as women to win an inheritance, but that creates romantic complications in “Leading Ladies.” \n\n Curtain Players will present Ken Ludwig’s comedy, which will open with a preview Thursd…
data.text:
Two actors pose as women to win an inheritance, but that creates romantic complications in “Leading Ladies.”

Curtain Players will present Ken Ludwig’s comedy, which will open with a preview Thursday in Galena.

“It’s a farce about love and normalcy … with quite a bit of physical slapstick,” director Michael Fusco said.

“Ludwig’s approach to farce is a little more polished and sophisticated. … His dialogue is sharp, and his situations are extremely clever.”

Set in 1952 in Pennsylvania, the two-act, 2-hour, 15-minute play revolves around Leo Clark and Jack Gable, two mediocre British actors reduced to putting on Shakespearean scenes in fraternal lodges.

They are out of money when Leo hears about Florence Snider, a dying woman in nearby York, Pennsylvania. According to Leo’s misreading of a newspaper story, Snider is looking for her long-lost nephews so she can leave them most of her $3 million fortune.

Leo and Jack decide to impersonate the woman’s adult nephews, Max and Steve — until they learn that the missing nephews are actually nieces.

“Undaunted by that fact, the two guys decide to pose as Maxine and Stephanie,” Fusco said.

Steve Salyer plays the double role of Leo and Maxine.

“In the beginning, all Leo wants is money, but by the end, he wants love and security, home and family,” Salyer said.

Jack Gable (Jaimie Schwartz) has been Leo’s reluctant acting partner for years.

“We’re good mates, but Leo’s the one who keeps it going,” Salyer said. “Jack really isn’t as dedicated. Only Leo could convince Jack to spend time doing something as fraught with disaster as touring Amish country in the 1950s performing Shakespeare at Moose lodges.”

Salyer had never played a woman onstage.

“It’s daunting and exciting,” he said.

“Growing up as a gay man in the ’70s and ’80s, I spent the first half of my life repressing every gesture that could possibly be interpreted as ‘feminine.’ In this play, I can finally forget all that … and simply have fun exploring this wonderful character.”

Playing a woman credibly is key to the show, Salyer said.

“It’s a complete transformation. … When Jaimie and I play Stephanie and Maxine, the audience has to be convinced that the other characters believe that we’re women,” he said.

Audrey-Marie Craddick plays Meg Snider, who is in line for one-third of Florence’s fortune.

“She’s a big-city girl in a small town,” Craddick said. “Meg has all these ambitions and dreams she wants to accomplish, but she can’t do that in York, Pennsylvania.”

Meg is engaged to marry the much-older Duncan, a stuffy minister, when she meets gender-disguised Leo and Jack. Leo falls in love with her.

“They completely turn her world upside down. She adores the fact that she has cousins, which she never had before,” Craddick said. “She really clicks with (Maxine) because Maxine is in the theater, and Meg adores theater.”

Craddick appreciates Ludwig’s work after seeing “Leading Ladies” elsewhere and viewing his Broadway comedies “Lend Me a Tenor” and “Moon Over Buffalo.”

“Ludwig is brilliant, especially with the comic timing,” she said. “A big part of what makes his comedies funny is that the audience knows something that the characters are oblivious to, yet it’s so obvious. … My favorite part of being onstage is reading lines that make people laugh.”
